Spectre [Kocher et al., 2019] Spectre is an attack exploiting speculative execution to leak secrets ‚ó¶ It is part of a recent wave of micro-architectural attacks, i.e., attacks using side-channels induced by the micro-architecture of a processor (e.g., cache, timers, virtual memory, ‚Ä¶) ‚ó¶ ‚ÄúSpectre [‚Ä¶] transiently bypasses software-defined security policies (e.g., bounds checking, function call/return abstractions, memory stores) to leak secrets out of the program‚Äôs intended code/data paths.‚Äù [Canella et al., 2019] (ÔÉü bit outdated, but a good survey on Spectre!) ‚ó¶ Many variants, here an updated version https://transient.fail/ 16 [Kocher et al., 2019] P. For example ‚ó¶ The attacker: 1. Looks for a piece of ‚Äúvulnerable code‚Äù (code gadget) including a condition (next slide) 2. Runs that code multiple times with an input s.t. the condition always holds (so training the branch predictor to take the ‚Äútrue‚Äù branch) 3. Then, runs the code with a specially-crafted input making the condition false: now the CPU mis-speculates and executes the ‚Äútrue‚Äù branch with wrong data (!!!) 4. Finally, it looks for information left behind after the CPU discovered it mis-speculated and rolled-back the computation (e.g., contents of caches) 17 Spectre v1 18 Spectre v1 18 1.
